awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Rates of lineage, phenotypic, and genomic diversification in replicated radiations of murine rodents
awd_abstract_narration:
Much of the diversity of life has arisen through the process of adaptive radiation. Adaptive radiation occurs when a group rapidly diversifies into many species to fill a variety of ecological roles. While adaptive radiation is a common theme in the evolution of life, many of its features are poorly understood. This project seeks to better understand how adaptive radiation proceeds. The project will examine the rate of diversification in genes, morphology and species diversity over the evolutionary history of a group of rodents containing more than 600 species. The study will determine how changes in genes, morphology and species are correlated as the species diversified. Importantly, the group under study contains the common lab mouse and rat, two species that serve as scientific models in medical and basic research. This study will place these model organisms in an evolutionary context that will allow scientists to better understand how their genes and other characteristics have evolved. Such understanding provides new insight into genes and characteristics of medical significance. Scientific meetings organized by the researchers will bring together scientists who study mice and rats from different perspectives, including molecular biology and medicine, to share insight and generate new research questions. In addition to the broader impacts on basic science and medicine, public outreach and education events at participating natural history museums will use the results of this research to teach principles of evolutionary biology to K-12 students and improve public understanding of science.

This project integrates comparative genomics with quantitative morphology in a rigorous phylogenetic framework to illuminate the dynamics of diversification in lineages, phenotypes, and genes across the most species-rich adaptive radiation in mammals. The exceptional species and ecomorphological diversity in rats and mice (subfamily Murinae, 634 living species) arose over the last 14 million years through replicate adaptive radiations, primarily in the distinct biogeographic units of Indo-Australia. This research will expand on the genomic resources from the leading mammalian model organisms to encompass the diversity of murine rodents by sequencing whole exomes from a large, phylogenetically dispersed set of species. In addition, the project will generate high-resolution, 3D morphometric models of cranial and post-cranial skeletons from the same species. The project will combine these distinct data layers to: estimate a species-level phylogeny of the Murinae; identify and date biogeographic and ecological transitions; estimate diversification rate shifts across the phylogeny; estimate rates of phenotypic and molecular evolution relative to transitions (biogeographic and ecological) and shifts in lineage diversification rate; test for correlations between the tempos of phenotypic and molecular evolution; and, quantify morphological and molecular convergence.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The diversity of life has been shaped by patterns of adaptation, speciation, and extinction. Instances where the origin of new species outpaces extinction are known as evolutionary radiations and are often associated with the rapid evolution of diverse trait innovations. Such radiations provide compelling opportunities to understand the process of speciation and how adaptation to new or changing environments shapes patterns of biodiversity.  However, the ultimate causes of diversification often remain unclear because patterns of trait evolution have seldom been integrated with biogeographic history and evolution at the molecular level. These limitations are particularly stark when considering the evolution of genes at the scale of whole genomes, largely because it has remained intractable to analyze large scale genomic data across very large radiations. Old World mice and rats represent a striking evolutionary radiation that has given rise to more than 10% of all living mammals over the last ~14 million years as the group repeatedly colonized Eurasia, Africa, and Indo-Australia. The two most powerful mammalian model genetic organisms (lab mouse and rat) emerged from this radiation, providing powerful genetic and genomic resources for a broad range of basic and applied research. However, most genetic studies of mice and rats have focused on these two model species, leaving most of the vast diversity of this group unexplored.

This project combined genome sequencing with quantitative trait analysis to illuminate the dynamics of diversification in species, traits, and genes across the most species-rich adaptive radiation in mammals. We sequenced all genes (whole exomes) within the genomes of 211 species of mice and rats, representing one of the largest comparative exome datasets ever generated in mammals. We then combined these data with available information on trait variation, ecological associations, diet specialization, and reproduction to better understand the connections between trait and molecular evolution. To support these activities, we also developed several analytical pipelines and tools that enable genome-scale analysis of evolutionary radiations, all of which have been made freely available to the research community.

Using our novel tools and genomic dataset, we reconstructed the evolutionary history of one of the largest and most species-rich radiations of mammals. We discovered extensive variation in evolutionary histories across regions of the genome among species, but relatively little evidence for hybridization between species. However, we did observe some bursts of hybridization following the colonization of some island archipelagos, which suggests an important role for genetic exchange between species during rapid species radiations. In-depth analysis of genetic variation across the genomes of some species provided surprising insights into the molecular and evolutionary processes that shape patterns of genetic relatedness across species. These results revealed a complex relationship between the analytical approaches used to reconstruct evolutionary histories (phylogenies) and basic aspects of genome biology, and underscore how failure to account for this complexity can mislead comparative studies. Focusing on molecular evolution, we also found that genes involved in immune defense, reproduction, and diet have been subject to pervasive rapid evolution during the diversification of mice and rats, with more positive natural selection associated with dietary specialization (i.e., carnivores and herbivores) when compared to generalist diets (i.e., omnivores). We also found that differences in reproductive biology and behavior had a strong influence on the evolution of both sperm traits and the genes underlying sperm development. Thus, understanding evolution across the extensive biodiversity of mice and rats provided basic insights into mammalian fertility. Collectively, these findings reveal a link between molecular evolution and diet, habitat specialization, and reproduction, and highlight specific genes and gene functions that have played important roles in the extensive and rapid diversification of mice and rats.

The COVID-19 pandemic caused extensive disruptions that delayed several of our focal projects. In the face of these unexpected challenges, this project has generated three peer-reviewed publications, three preprint manuscripts currently under evaluation, with several more scientific publications under development. Our extensive genetic data have been deposited in public archives for release upon publication. Likewise, all analytical tools are open source and deposited in publicly available repositories, with publication of technical application notes planned for the coming year. This project also yielded tremendous training opportunities for several early career scientists, including major contributions to one defended doctoral dissertation, and training in research and teaching for two postdoctoral researchers who have since advanced on to tenure-track faculty or senior staff positions at major academic institutions.
